title: Wednesday, 19th July, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Morning

PM11:01am

I'm guessing everyone's seen the news

PM11:01am

South African inflation at it's lowest level since November 2015

11:01 am
PM11:02am

https://www.ft.com...-a457-4f195c2127d7

PM11:02am

Yeah, it's like that Omg smile

PM11:02am

Actually, there is news around -- but much of it is abroad

11:02 am
PM11:03am

Zalando getting smashed yesterday in Germany

PM11:03am

Blue Apron getting whacked in the US

PM11:03am

Amazon factor

11:03 am
PM11:03am

And then there's other odd-ball stuff, like this chap...

PM11:03am

PM11:03am

George Economou

11:04 am
PM11:04am

Boss and controlling shareholder of a Greek shipping concern -- Dryships

PM11:04am

You can get background here: https://ftalphavil...ty-in-this-market/

PM11:04am

Mind-boggling

11:05 am
PM11:05am

He's got a scheme going whereby Dryships sells stock at a discount to a Marshall Islands-listed entity

PM11:05am

Which then dumps the stock on unsuspecting US investors

PM11:06am

The market price collapses -- and Dryships then does a stock consolidation to keep the price about $1

11:05 am
PM11:06am

And avoid suspension

PM11:06am

Economou keeps doing this

PM11:06am

Did it again last night

11:06 am
PM11:06am

Price had collapsed to 50 cents or something

PM11:07am

he's done a 1-for-7 "reverse split" -- as they call it in the US

PM11:07am

Everyone's suing him and the company

11:07 am
PM11:07am

But he just says "go hang"

PM11:07am

We're listed in the Marshall Islands and US courts don't count there

PM11:07am

Nuts

11:07 am
undefined
BE11:08am

So ............

PM11:08am

Footsie's up a tad

11:08 am
BE11:08am

It is! Though you're right to say there's not much around in the way of news.

BE11:08am

I mean, look at the Times ....

BE11:08am

11:08 am
BE11:09am

Rip-off fees for using credit cards to be banned

BE11:09am

Yeah, we know.

BE11:09am

It's an EU directive

11:09 am
PM11:09am

hehe

BE11:09am

That's been in place for yonks.

BE11:09am

And most people, I thought, knew about.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Seems not though!

Just Eat PLC (JE.:LSE): Last: 669.00, down 46 (-6.43%), High: 714.50, Low: 648.00, Volume: 6.35m
PM11:10am

Oh dear

11:10 am
BE11:10am

I mean, there are lots of good reasons to sell Just Sell, but this really isn't one of them.

PM11:10am

What's happened there?

BE11:11am

Well, Just Eat gets .... wait, let me check, 13% of revenue from card fees.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Or did last year.

PM11:11am

Oh i see. Sorry, being slow

BE11:11am

And clearly, that mostly drops straight to the bottom line because transaction fees aren't actually there for anything other than profiteering.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Doe this matter? Not much.

BE11:13am

Goldman attempts to take a circumspect approach to its analysis, rather than simply calling its clients dolts for selling.

BE11:13am

2/3 of Just Eat’s UK orders are paid via card, contributing c£30mn in revenue in
2016. At the EBITDA level this is c.27% of 2016 Group EBITDA. However, we believe
the net impact of any legislation will be much less than this because:
1) We believe Just Eat provides a very valuable route to market for its restaurants in
the UK and access to far more customers than any other UK platform. As such, we
believe restaurants will be willing to share the burden of any lost revenues due to
this law change.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

2) Just Eat is still in the early stages of developing the suite of additional services it
offers restaurants, which they are yet to monetise. A key one of these being
providing services and purchasing on a bulk pricing basis, negotiating reduced fees
for its fragmented base of restaurant customers. This is in addition to business
analysis and consultancy type services based on its vast dataset that Just Eat can
provide to restaurants. We believe these represent services restaurants would be
very willing to pay for, which would mitigate any lost card fees.

BE11:13am

3) Providing card processing for its restaurant base is a valuable service, for which
we believe restaurants will be willing to pay.

BE11:14am

4) The law is yet to be finalised. There is relevant cost that Just Eat are paying to
Visa/Mastercard etc which Just Eat could be allowed to recoup. The size of this
recoverable amount is not clear from the articles we have seen, but could still allow the charging of a relevant (though most likely smaller) fee by those collecting card payments.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Barclays is less circumspect, basically calling its clients dolts for selling.

BE11:15am

This is simply the UK’s implementation of a European directive, which we have addressed many times in our payments research. Under PSD2, such surcharges will be banned in the whole of the EU from January 2018 onwards. However, the share price reaction would suggest that the market’s interpretation is that Just Eat can no longer charge card processing fees to its restaurant customers and that it will lose its card processing revenue. This is incorrect, and Just Eat’s business model is not directly impacted by this legislation.

BE11:15am

Just Eat currently charges all its restaurants a flat fee for card transactions, averaging 50p. Currently, the restaurants can then decide whether to pass this cost on to their customers, and we suspect a majority of restaurants do this. For consumers this means that up to 50p is added to the total bill during the checkout process, if they decide to pay via cards. In the future, restaurants won’t be able to charge the fee to consumers anymore, suggesting a negative impact on the restaurant, not Just Eat. For reference, we estimate that card processing fees for Just Eat account for c. 12% of revenue. However, these have a relatively high associated cost of sales and therefore would account for a lesser percentage of gross profit.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

In reality, much like in the airline and other industries, it is likely that the merchant will simply raise prices to cover this or will add generic admin fees to online bookings, regardless of payment method. In effect, this would mean that cash (and debit card) payers would be substituting those who pay by credit card. One could argue that the restaurants will push Just Eat to lower its processing fees as a result of this legislation, but we see the bargaining power of the restaurants as relatively limited in this situation.

BE11:15am

To conclude, we therefore see the market reaction as misinterpreting the news flow on this issue, and would expect the stock to recover. Just Eat trades at 28x/23x FY18/19E PE and we are Overweight.

BE11:16am

I've been hunting around for some estimated exposures elsewhere. Easyjet, Ryanair, Domino's .....

11:15 am
PM11:16am

hmm

easyJet plc (EZJ:LSE): Last: 1,382, down 31.35 (-2.22%), High: 1,422, Low: 1,374, Volume: 1.30m
Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYA:LSE): Last: 18.62, down 0.24 (-1.27%), High: 18.95, Low: 18.31, Volume: 697.62k
11:16 am
Domino's Pizza Group PLC (DOM:LSE): Last: 279.80, down 4.4 (-1.55%), High: 286.40, Low: 279.10, Volume: 675.22k
BE11:17am

.... Merrill puts the total impact on the airlines at 1% of earnings, which isn't terribly scary, though I've not seen a breakout chart.

BE11:17am

However, the point to emphasise is: we know!

11:18 am
BE11:18am

If the removal of gouge fees was not in your earnings model previously, it was your earnings model that was the problem.

PM11:18am

Indeed

undefined
11:18 am
PM11:19am

Hey, the Takeover Panel annual report is out!

PM11:19am

Knew there was fresh news somewhere

PM11:19am

Have you ever read the Panel's annual report?

11:19 am
PM11:19am

It's a beautiful document

BE11:19am

(@Soundbuy: imagine being at Glastonbury and having to stay sober for nine hours. It's no jolly.)

BE11:19am

Go on, do you have the link?

11:19 am
PM11:19am

Lovely prose

PM11:20am

Starts off by reminding everyone, in beautiful English, what the Panel is

PM11:20am

www.thetakeoverpan...Panel-ARA-2017.pdf

11:20 am
PM11:20am

The essential characteristics of the Panel system are flexibility, certainty and speed,enabling parties to know where they stand under the Code in a timely fashion. Thesecharacteristics are important in order to avoid over-rigid rules and the risk of takeoversbecoming delayed by litigation of a tactical nature, which may frustrate the ability of offereecompany shareholders to decide the outcome of an offer.

PM11:20am

Etc

PM11:21am

Required reading for US corporate financiers

11:21 am
PM11:21am

They should get one

PM11:21am

A Panel, that is

undefined
11:21 am
BE11:22am

To M&A? Of sorts?

PM11:22am

Sure

BE11:22am

Reckitt flogging mustard.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

For a frankly extraordinary £3.2bn.

PM11:22am

And not to Unilever

BE11:22am

McCormick is the sucker here.

11:22 am
BE11:23am

7x Sales

BE11:23am

20x EBITDA

BE11:23am

Street was only expecting £2bn for this.

11:23 am
PM11:23am

For French's mustard

PM11:23am

It is extraordinary

BE11:24am

Sale is 2.4% dilutive to Reckitt earnings but more importantly will cut debt to 2.2x vs 2.9x

11:24 am
BE11:24am

McCormick, I assume, will be sharply lower on this.

BE11:25am

It's difficult to map out any kind of argument that says they haven't overpaid.

BE11:25am

Okay, so $50m back loaded towards 2020.

11:25 am
BE11:26am

But the rest of it is “substantial growth and increased household penetration” by leveraging “international infrastructure."

BE11:26am

........... because Reckitt starved these brands? Or ran them flabby?

BE11:26am

Reckitt did this?

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Sheesh. Good luck.

BE11:27am

Anyway, it all plays into the Reckitt 2.0 theme. Revivified growth and so forth.

BE11:27am

Here's Morgan Stanley.

11:01 am
PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

BE11:28am

(I'd fine any analyst, or journalist for that matter, who says "cuts the mustard" in coverage today.)

BE11:29am

We have modelled three potential
structures for RB by 2020: 1) RB + Mead with no disposals, 2) RB ex-Food
assuming a sale for a conservative £1.9bn and 3) RB ex-Food, ex-Portfolio and exHome. All three show RB in 2020 right at the top of the large-cap FMCG peer
group: 5-6% top-line growth, 6-8% profit growth and 8-10% EPS growth. The
hypothetical Health and Hygiene pure play shows the most attractive growth
and returns with a ROIC of greater than 20%. We continue to believe the real prize for both
investors and RB management is neither the short-term optical top-line
acceleration in 2H17-1H18, nor mechanical accretion from the Mead deal, but RB
2020: structural growth on high margins, with a balance sheet ready to be
deployed again. The sale of the Food business for a price well above expectations will help to allay short-term concerns in our view

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Okay, so here's what I don't get.

PM11:30am

Go on

BE11:30am

Aldi and Lidl have 7% and 5% of the UK grocery market respectively. They're non branded.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

And growing sales at 20% or thereabouts.

BE11:31am

At the same time, branded food companies are paying 23x for branded foods.

PM11:32am

But it's not the UK that McCormick's targeting, surely

11:31 am
BE11:32am

And analysts are writing about how the price "confirms the wider asset value of unique staples assets" ......

PM11:32am

(It will be China, i suspect)

BE11:32am

Are we saying the UK grocery market is unique? Because it isn't. If anything, it's just rather quicker to develop.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

So, yeah, maybe it's all an emerging markets story.

PM11:32am

Yeah, I see your point

BE11:33am

.... because I can't see how both these trends co-exist.

11:33 am
undefined
PM11:34am

McCormack is the market leader in Ketchup in China, ive just learnt.

PM11:34am

http://www.mccormi...ds/McCormick-China

11:34 am
PM11:34am

But what else is there?

BE11:34am

Oh, right. The ketchup in China market.

BE11:35am

11:35 am
Premier Foods PLC (PFD:LSE): Last: 40.00, no change, High: 40.75, Low: 40.00, Volume: 520.98k

11:36 am

BE11:37am

11:37 am

madrugada -- no

11:38 am

PM11:39am

PM11:39am

11:40 am
undefined

And on that theme, where now?

PM11:41am

There's a few dull statements

11:40 am
PM11:41am

PM11:41am

PM11:42am

QinetiQ -- taht's gone down badly!

11:42 am
Qinetiq Group PLC (QQ.:LSE): Last: 251.30, down 23.1 (-8.42%), High: 274.60, Low: 247.40, Volume: 2.94m
PM11:42am

Ouch

PM11:42am

https://www.invest...1707190700034341L/

11:42 am
PM11:43am

Seems a harsh reaction

PM11:43am

Let me get one of those UBS Q&A things to explain

BE11:43am

Outlook unchanged, I thought?

11:43 am
PM11:43am

Q: What were the most noteworthy areas of Q1 IMS?
QinetiQ issued a qualitative trading statement re-iterating FY18 outlook. Q1 trading was aligned with the company expectations. Nevertheless the company flags some deferred customer contract award decisions in EMEA Services being deferred or delayed reflecting in our opinion a more tempered outlook on the UK defence budget click here . Q1 Global Products underlying revenues were down ~10% y/y (UBSe) and Q1 BtB less than1

PM11:43am

Q: How did the results compare vs. expectations?
Q1 revenues similar to last year in EMEA Services was aligned with our expectations. Global Products Q1 revenues were similar to last year including a contribution from the Meggitt Targets acquisition (UBSe ~£5m) – this implies underlying revenues down ~10% y/y (UBSe). After a weak order intake in H2 FY17 (0.6x BtB), Q1 Global Products order intake has also seen some deferrals with our understanding that BtB remained below 1x. QinetiQ expects to catch up on orders in the next quarters.

PM11:44am

Q: Has the company's guidance/outlook changed?
Guidance was reaffirmed although order intake in EMEA Services however we believe the weaker order intake in EMEA Services and Global products still leaves downside risks to revenue/profits full year.

11:44 am
PM11:44am

Valuation: trades on 12.5x 2018E EV/EBITA, and 16.5x 2018 P/E
We believe investors' key focus will be on: i) order intake in Global Products; ii) progress on the integration of the Targets business recently acquired from Meggitt; iii) comments around the order activity and payment terms of the MoD

BE11:44am

Ah okay, it's a May year end (so of course the outlook is unchanged) whereas the new bit is the slower start to orders than expectations.

PM11:44am

Yeah, that seems to be it

11:44 am
PM11:45am

Although an 8% share price hit does seem harsh

BE11:45am

As per Barclays .........

BE11:45am

As a reminder, at the beginning of FY18E EMEA Services had 79% of revenue under contract versus 77% at the beginning of FY17. It is also worth noting that orders in H1 last year were boosted by the receipt of the £109m 11-yr renewal for the UK Naval Combat System Integration Support Services (NCISS) and $28m US aircraft carriers. Therefore we expect to see a reduction in orders booked YoY at the interims.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

Also no formal guidance on Global Products, which I think is those nets they throw over tanks.

BE11:46am

Our estimates for H1 assume a c. 44%/56% H1/H2 weighting to EBITA, similar to last year (ie H1 18E EBITA of £49.9m vs. £51.9m last year).

undefined
11:48 am
BE11:48am

Am I alone in not even beginning to care less what BBC presenters are paid?

BE11:49am

I mean, it's keeping the rabble entertained which is good. But honestly, who gives a stuff?

BE11:49am

Let's try to stick to the day job.

11:49 am
PM11:49am

Easier said than done today tho Bryce

BE11:50am

I think Drax was mentioned some time ago

Drax Group PLC (DRX:LSE): Last: 331.70, down 13.8 (-3.99%), High: 337.60, Low: 312.70, Volume: 1.51m
11:51 am
BE11:51am

Slight miss, nothing dramatic.

BE11:52am

Full year guidance remains unchanged,

BE11:52am

The most interesting news in there, at the margin, is that fourth turbine is being returned to burning coal for winter 2017.

11:52 am
PM11:53am

Thought we'd seen the back of coal

BE11:53am

That's the ambition. But woodchip not currently washing its face

BE11:53am

That's American imported woodchip, of course.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

Here's Credit Suisse.

BE11:54am

 Full year EBITDA guidance is unchanged with a statement that “2017 expectations unchanged”.
Reuters consensus was £225m in February and is currently £234m. We are at £224m, albeit we note
ROC price have increased. We expect EBITDA growth into FYdec18E given a full year of Opus or the
Louisiana Pellets acquisition, and absence of a 70-day statutory outage on the unit with a CfD.
 We expect 2017 to be the first year of growth year since 2010. Without the biomass conversion plans,
Drax would be c£50m p.a. loss-making at the EBITDA level, on our counterfactual. Hence there is a
large marginal benefit from the biomass growth plans of the past 10 years, albeit the base has fallen
c£300m through CO2 policy and weak gas-versus-coal prices.

BE11:54am

 H1dec17A EBITDA was £121m (CS est. £120m, PY £70m), adjusted EBIT was £31m (CS est. £22m,
PY £18m) and Underlying EPS was 2.2p (CS est. 5.3p). Underlying interest was £19m, which was
c£4m higher than we expected. DPS was c4.9p, being c40% of the full-year c£50m. We forecast 4.1p,
but remain at 12.3p for the full year.
 EBIT margins in supply were c1.1%, or c£11m. Haven is breakeven and Opus makes c£35m EBITDA
annualised (only 4.5 months contribution) hence this is consistent with what we would expect.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

 There was a strong working capital inflow due to lower stock levels (+£114m) which meant that net
debt was low (+£372m). While we didn’t forecast net debt, this appears to us to be good. We would
expect some reversal in H2. The company still forecasts net debt:EBITDA smaller than 2x. Capex guidance for the full year is £170-180m, but there is additional spend from a new office, and lasalle is £50m all-in.

PM11:55am

(PhoenixOyster -- think the planning application was blocked)

BE11:55am

 There were large exceptional costs in H1. We forecast c£24m of exceptional costs related to the
refinancing, and these came through, but also with Opus acquisition costs of c£6m and a c£65m
unrealized FX gain. The underlying interest charge (c£30m PY) should be the same.
 The company is still focused on a conversion of Unit 4 to burning biomass. But the unit is being
returned to burning coal, will have an outage in 2018, and Drax will do more research and
development after that. It appears to us that more work is required to get load factors up. We think the
trials will have gone poorly, given how unattractive burning coal is right now. We also think this is
partly a message to the Government to restore grandfathering rights.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

Action
Drax trades on EV/EBITDA of c8.1x in 2017E and c6.1x in 2018E. Our DCF-based SOTP gets to our
400p/share TP. Our power price forecasts are c£2-£4/MWh above the forward curve to 2020, and broadly in line thereafter. We see strong FCF generation (c13% FCF yield to EV) and more sustainable business streams post 2027.

PM11:56am

( http://www.richbor...anning-application )

BE11:57am

(@Boncoeur: are you really trying to repurpose nosiness in other people's wages as a social justice cause? I admire the ingenuity.)

11:56 am
undefined

Nearly there.

PM11:58am

Yeah, nearly

11:58 am
BE11:58am

In the junk end of the market, I was surprised this morning to see The People's Operator still going.

People's Operator PLC (TPOP:LSE): Last: 2.58, down 0.175 (-6.36%), High: 2.58, Low: 2.58, Volume: 736.59k
PM11:59am

11:59 am

Wales as chairman.

BE11:59am

BE12:00pm

BE12:00pm

12:01 pm

As we noted way back in 2014: https://ftalphavil...00m-mvno/?mhq5j=e1

BE12:02pm

Thumbs up

PM12:02pm

12:03 pm
PM12:03pm

PM12:03pm

PM12:03pm

12:03 pm
PM12:03pm

ML will close for the first two weeks of August

PM12:03pm

PM12:04pm

12:04 pm
PM12:04pm

BE11:28am

$4.2bn or 23x EV/EBITDA [...] more than cuts the mustard in our view. This is significantly above all prevailing multiples for a developed market food business, and above prior press reports of £2-2.2bn and consensus at ~£2bn / $2.6bn. Importantly, it reduces the outstanding debt from ~£14.7bn to ~£11.6bn, and the net debt to EBITDA ratio from 4.1x to 3.3X. More broadly, it confirms the wider asset value of unique staples assets (French's is the No.1 global mustard brand and the No.1 in the US market).
